FFNet::FFNet ( const unsigned  in = 0,
const unsigned  out = 0 
)

Creates an empty feed-forward network with "in" input neurons and "out" output neurons.

Constructor no. 1

Only the input and output dimensions are set, but the network will contain no neurons.

Parameters:
in Dimension of the input (no. of input neurons).
out Dimension of the output (no. of output neurons).
Returns:
None.

FFNet::FFNet ( const unsigned  in,
const unsigned  out,
const Array< int > &  cmat 
)

Creates a feed-forward network with "in" input neurons and "out" output neurons.

Additionally, the array "cmat" determines the topology (i.e., number of neurons and their connections).

Definition at line 681 of file FFNet.cpp.

FFNet::FFNet ( const unsigned  in,
const unsigned  out,
const Array< int > &  cmat,
const Array< double > &  wmat 
)

Creates a feed-forward network with "in" input neurons and "out" output neurons.

Additionally, the arrays "cmat" and "wmat" determine the topology (i.e., number of neurons and their connections) as well as the connection weights.

This destructor is used to replace the standard destructor, created by the compiler, because internal pointer variables must be deleted, too.

Member Function Documentation

void FFNet::activate ( const Array< double > &  in  )  [inline, protected]

The input pattern "in" is used to activate the neurons of the net and produce some result at the output neurons.

The input vector in contains a pattern given to the input neurons. The input will be propagated through the network and produce some "reaction" at the output neurons, depending one the weights of the single connections. The activation of the input neurons is done by

so the input neurons only propagate the input values. For the further propagation of the input values through the hidden to the output neurons, sigmoid activation functions given by the methods g and gOutput are used.

Parameters:
in The input pattern.
Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
stable

void FFNet::backprop (  )  [inline, protected]

Performs a backpropagation to calculate the derivatives of the outputs with respect to the parameters of the network.

The values of the output neurons that were produced by an input pattern before are used for a backpropagation to calculate the partial derivatives of the model function with respect to the parameters

Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002

int& FFNet::connection ( unsigned  i,
unsigned  j 
) [inline]

Returns the value at position of the connection matrix.

If a connection exists from neuron no. to neuron no. with , then the function will return "1". If there is no connection or if then the function will return zero.
If you have a matrix , then for will indicate the status of the connection between the neuron no. and the bias value. For all input neurons, this status value is always zero.

Parameters:
i Connection end point.
j Connection start point.

Status of connection .

void FFNet::df ( const Array< double > &  coeffs,
Array< double > &  dfdw 
) [inline, virtual]

Calculates the model's general derivative.

After a call of model, df calculates the gradient and stores it in dfdw. The coefficients can be chosen freely.

The point of this function is that for many models, the complexity of calculating this linear combination of gradients is the same as of calculating a single output gradient

Via the chain rule, the gradient of _any_ (e.g., error) functional can be calculated.

Example 1: Let , then

is the parameter gradient of an MSE with respect to target values .

Example 2: Let , then the gradients of only the th output will be calculated:

and

This example is invoked when dmodel calculates the gradient of each output with respect to the parameters.

The default implementation is the approximation df_app(c, dcf_w, dcf_x).

Parameters:
c the corefficients in the formula above.
dfdw the calculated model's general derivative.
Returns:
None.
Author:
M. Toussaint, C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
under construction

Reimplemented from ModelInterface.

Array< double > &  output 
) [virtual]

Reads in one input pattern for the Feed Forward Net model and calculates the derivatives of the resulting network output with respect to the weights.

Furthermore, the network output is given back.

void FFNet::dmodel ( const Array< double > &  input  )  [inline, virtual]

Reads in one input pattern for the Feed Forward Net model and calculates the derivatives of the resulting network output with respect to the weights.

The single input pattern in is used to activate the neurons of the network. The results, given in the output neurons are then used to calculate the derivatives of the output with respect to the weights of the network.

Parameters:
input The single input pattern. If more than one pattern is given, the method exits with failure.
Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:

double FFNet::g ( double  a  )  [protected, virtual]

Activation function of the hidden neurons.

The activation function is used for the propagation of the input through the network. Given a network with neurons, including input neurons and output neurons, the sigmoid activation function for the hidden neuron with index is given as

where as the propagated result of the input for the previous neurons is calculated as

and denotes the bias term.

Parameters:
a Input for the activation function, see above.

.

void FFNet::initWeights ( double  l = -.5,
double  h = .5 
) [inline, virtual]

Initializes the weights of the net.

The weight values of the network are initialized with uniformly distributed random numbers.

Parameters:
l Lower bound for weight random numbers, default value is "-0.5".

void FFNet::initWeights ( long  seed = 42,
double  l = -.5,
double  h = .5 
) [virtual]

Initializes the random number generator and the weights of the net.

After initializing the random number generator with a seed value, the weight values of the network are initialized with uniformly distributed random numbers.

Parameters:
seed Initialization value for random number generator, default value is "42".
l Lower bound for weight random numbers, default value is "-0.5".
h Upper bound for weight random numbers, default value is "0.5".
Returns:
None.

void FFNet::model ( const Array< double > &  input,
Array< double > &  output 
) [inline, virtual]

Uses the input pattern(s) input for the Feed Forward Net model to produce the output vector(s) output.

The given input pattern(s) in input are propagated forward through the net by using the activate function for all patterns sequentially. After each propagation the result in the output neurons is stored in the output vector(s) output.

Parameters:
input Input pattern(s) for the model.
output Output vector(s).
Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
activate

Implements ModelInterface.

FFNet& FFNet::operator= ( const FFNet &  net  )  [inline]

Assigns the data of network "net" to the current network.

This operator is defined in order to prevent the implicit definition by the compiler, because a feed forward network includes dynamic structures, that must be properly assigned.

Parameters:
net Second network, whose data is assigned to the current network.
Returns:
A reference to the current network (after assignment).

double FFNet::outputValue ( unsigned  i  )  [inline]

Returns the output value of neuron no. "i".

Given an index i, the function returns the value, that was calculated by the activation function for the neuron no. i for the last given input pattern.

void FFNet::readParameters (  ) 

Reads the parameters (weight and bias values) from the parameter vector ModelInterface::w and stores them in the weightMatrix.

In feed forward networks connections and the corresponding weights can exist only from neurons with no. to neurons with no. with . So to save space, the parameters, i.e. the values for the connection weights are internally stored in a vector. But a matrix offers a more concise view so this function reads in the parameter vector ModelInterface::w and writes the values to the weightMatrix.

Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
stable

void FFNet::resize (  )  [protected, virtual]

Reserves memory for all internal net data structures.

For the internal administration of a network several dynamic data structures are used. Based on the size of the connectionMatrix and the values of ModelInterface::inputDimension and ModelInterface::outputDimension, the memory for all other data is reserved.

Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel

const Array< double > &  wmat 
)

Based on a given connectionMatrix and a weightMatrix the structure of the current network is modified.

Definition at line 855 of file FFNet.cpp.

References connectionMatrix, resize(), weightMatrix, and writeParameters().

void FFNet::setStructure ( const Array< double > &  wmat,
bool  preserve = false 
)

Based on a given weightMatrix the structure of the current network is modified.

This function will use the values of ModelInterface::inputDimension, ModelInterface::outputDimension and the information in the given weightMatrix wmat to change the structure of the network. An existing connection matrix (that is compatible to the the new weightMatrix wmat) can be adopted or a new one will be created with the data of the weightMatrix.

Parameters:
wmat The weightMatrix that provides the basis information for the modification of the network.
preserve If set to "true", the existing connectionMatrix will be kept. In case of inconsistency between the weightMatrix and the connectionMatrix the function will exit with failure.
Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
2002-01-08, ci
Added some commands to remove memory leackage, that lead to crashes, too.
Status
stable

Definition at line 955 of file FFNet.cpp.

void FFNet::setStructure ( const Array< int > &  cmat  ) 

Based on a given connectionMatrix the structure of the current network is modified.

This function will use the information in the given connectionMatrix cmat to modify the network. The weights for all neurons of the new connectionMatrix are initialized by zero.

Parameters:
cmat The connectionMatrix that provides the basis information for the creation of the network.
Returns:
None.

C. Igel

double& FFNet::weight ( unsigned  i,
unsigned  j 
) [inline]

Returns the weight value at position in the weight matrix.

The weight matrix corresponds to the connection matrix. If a connection exists from neuron no. to neuron no. with , then the function will return a weight value greater than zero for this connection. If there is no connection or if then the function will return zero.
If you have a matrix , then for will give the weight of the connection between the neuron no. and the bias value.

Parameters:
i Connection end point.
j Connection start point.
Returns:
The weight of the connection .
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
1999
Changes
none
Status
stable

void FFNet::writeParameters (  ) 

Reads the parameters (weight and bias values) from the weightMatrix and writes them to the parameter vector ModelInterface::w.

In feed forward networks connections and the corresponding weights can exist only from neurons with no. to neurons with no. with . So to save space, the parameters, i.e. the values for the connection weights are internally stored in a vector. But a matrix offers a more concise view so this function reads in the original (extended) weightMatrix and stores the values in the parameter vector ModelInterface::w.

Returns:
None.
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2002
Changes
none
Status
stable

Member Data Documentation

unsigned FFNet::bias [protected]

Index of bias weight in the weight matrix.

The bias term can be considered as an extra input neuron , whose activation is permanently set to . The index is used for direct access of the weight for the bias connection in the weight matrix.

See also:
weightMatrix

Definition at line 522 of file FFNet.h.

Referenced by activate(), backprop(), MSEFFNet::derror(), LMSEFFNet::derror(), df(), FFNet(), initWeights(), operator=(), readParameters(), resize(), setStructure(), and writeParameters().

Array< int > FFNet::connectionMatrix [protected]

Matrix that identifies the connection status between all neurons.

If the network consists of neurons, this is a matrix where a value of "1" at position denotes a connection between neuron to neuron with , a value of zero means no connection.
The last column of the matrix indicates the connection of the current neuron (given by the row number) to the bias value.
For all input neurons, this value is always zero.

See also:
weightMatrix

Definition at line 560 of file FFNet.h.

Referenced by activate(), connection(), FFNet(), getConnections(), initWeights(), operator<<(), operator=(), operator>>(), readParameters(), resize(), setStructure(), and writeParameters().

Array< double > FFNet::d [protected]

Used for temporary storage for the local gradient delta values for all output neurons.

Given a network with neurons, including input and output neurons, is a Array. The delta values for each output neuron are calculated in a backwards pass, starting with the output neurons. The delta values for output neuron are then given as:

for and

for . Taken these values as base, the delta values for the hidden neurons with index are calculated as:

where is the weight of an existing connection from neuron no. to neuron no. . These temporary values are then used for the calculation of the partial derivatives of the outputs with respect to the parameters as performed in backprop.

See also:
dg, dgOutput, backprop

unsigned FFNet::firstOutputNeuron [protected]

Index of the first output neuron.

This value is used for direct access of the output neurons, especially when working with the list z of activation results for all neurons.

unsigned FFNet::numberOfNeurons [protected]

Number of all network neurons.

This is the total number of neurons in the network, i.e. input, hidden and output neurons.

Array< double > FFNet::weightMatrix [protected]

Corresponding to the connectionMatrix, this matrix defines the weight of the considered connection.

If the network consists of neurons, this is a matrix where a value of at position denotes, that the connection between neuron to neuron with has a weight of . If in the connectionMatrix, then . For each neuron there is also a so-called bias term at the last position of each matrix row:
